title: Made in the U.S.A., but With a Supply-Chain Reboot
content: Facing delays, shortages and higher prices for raw materials, small manufacturers are finding new sources. Not all are able to pass along the costs.

title: With Omicron’s Arrival, Stocks Will Again Hang on Headlines
content: Stocks rose on Monday, but analysts expect a bumpy ride for share prices while experts assess whether existing vaccines will be effective against the new variant.

title: Twitter’s Jack Dorsey Steps Down From C.E.O. Role
content: The social media pioneer, whose name has become synonymous with the company, was replaced by Twitter’s chief technology officer, Parag Agrawal.

more_info.byline: By Kate Conger and Lauren Hirsch

title: Who Is Parag Agrawal, Twitter’s New C.E.O.?
content: A longtime Twitter insider and a confidant of co-founder Jack Dorsey, Mr. Agrawal takes over as the social media company confronts various challenges.

more_info.byline: By Mike Isaac, Kate Conger and Cade Metz

title: Elizabeth Holmes Says Former Boyfriend Abused Her
content: Ms. Holmes, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, blamed Ramesh Balwani, the former No. 2 at the company.

more_info.byline: By Erin Woo and Erin Griffith

title: Union Vote at Amazon Warehouse in Alabama Is Overturned by Regional Labor Office
content: Amazon said in August that it intended to appeal to the national labor board if it did not prevail at the regional level, but it did not say Monday whether it would follow through.

org_facet: Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union

title: Europe Revisits Nuclear Power as Climate Deadlines Loom
content: While wind and solar ramp up, several countries, including France and Britain, are looking to expand their nuclear energy programs. Germany and others aren’t so enthusiastic.

more_info.byline: By Liz Alderman and Stanley Reed

title: Millennials Confront High Inflation for the First Time
content: Americans born after 1980 have been wrestling with sharp price increases for the first time since they’ve been old enough to notice.

more_info.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Sara Chodosh and Ben Casselman

title: An Auto Show for the Raddest Cars of the ’80s and ’90s
content: Nostalgia mixes with tape decks and car phones at RADwood events that aim to capture “the essence of a bodacious era.”

title: Adolfo, Designer Who Dressed Nancy Reagan, Dies at 98
content: Adolfo, who began as a milliner and took inspiration from Chanel, was also a favorite of New York society women.

title: The Biden administration, under fire for supply chain woes, says stores will be fully stocked for the holidays.
content: President Biden has made a push to unclog ports, address trucker shortages and take other steps to alleviate the pressure created by consumers looking to buy couches, cars and electronics instead of eating out or going to theme parks.

more_info.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Ana Swanson

title: Omicron increases inflation uncertainty, the Fed chair will tell lawmakers.
content: Jerome H. Powell, who will appear before the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday, also plans to tell lawmakers that price gains could last well into 2022, according to prepared remarks.

more_info.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport

title: Chris Cuomo Played Outsize Role in Ex-Gov. Cuomo’s Defense
content: Chris Cuomo, the CNN host, participated in strategy discussions and shared a tip on at least one woman who had accused his brother, Andrew Cuomo, of sexual harassment.

more_info.byline: By Nicholas Fandos, Michael Gold, Grace Ashford and Dana Rubinstein

title: Who Owns a Recipe? A Plagiarism Claim Has Cookbook Authors Asking.
content: U.S. copyright law protects all kinds of creative material, but recipe creators are mostly powerless in an age and a business that are all about sharing.

title: Clearview AI, a facial recognition company, is fined for breach of Britain’s privacy laws.
content: The Information Commissioner’s Office said it fined Clearview AI for failing to inform British residents that it was collecting billions of photos from sites including Facebook, Instagram and LinkedIn to build its facial recognition software.

title: Arlene Dahl, Movie Star Turned Entrepreneur, Is Dead at 96
content: She had already started branching out when her film career was at its height, writing a syndicated column and launching a fashion and cosmetics business.

title: A Timeline of Jack Dorsey’s Twitter Tenure
content: A look at key moments from Dorsey’s tenure at the company.

title: Movie theaters must ‘urgently’ rethink the experience, a study says.
content: Nearly half of the prepandemic audience hasn’t returned, research shows, and 8 percent may be gone forever.

title: Black Friday sales were up, but reflected the challenges facing retailers.
content: Drawn by deals, consumers spread out their spending in the weeks leading up to the day after Thanksgiving.

title: In Scotland, Serving Halibut for a Better Planet
content: Scottish cooks and diners are putting sustainable fish and shellfish on the plate in a tangible (and delicious) move to curb the effects of climate change.

title: As Antiviral Pills Arrive, Can Testing Keep Up?
content: The pills must be given early in the course of infection, which means access to timely, accurate test results will be crucial.

title: A New Publishing Platform for Comic Books Will Give Creators a Greater Stake
content: Zestworld, which counts Alexis Ohanian as a supporter, will allow comic book writers and artists to present new work and reap the benefits.

title: Markets Aren’t That Spooked by Omicron
content: Investors are re-pricing the risks of the latest coronavirus variant.

more_info.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

title: A ‘Simpsons’ Episode Lampooned Chinese Censorship. In Hong Kong, It Vanished.
content: The episode mocked both Mao Zedong and the government’s efforts to suppress memory of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.

title: Hunt for the ‘Blood Diamond of Batteries’ Impedes Green Energy Push
content: Dangerous mining conditions plague Congo, home to the world’s largest supply of cobalt, a key ingredient in electric cars. A leadership battle threatens reforms.

more_info.byline: By Dionne Searcey, Eric Lipton and Ashley Gilbertson

title: Taliban and 9/11 Families Fight for Billions in Frozen Afghan Funds
content: The White House must figure out what to do with the Afghan central bank’s account at the Federal Reserve, now blocked under U.S. law.

title: Could Roads Recharge Electric Cars? The Technology May Be Close.
content: But challenges await, including technical issues, regulatory barriers and many miles of highway.

title: Markets rise as investors reconsider the unknowns of the Omicron variant.
content: After tumbling on Friday, the S&P 500 gained more than 1 percent. Oil prices and bond yields also rose.

more_info.byline: By Eshe Nelson and Coral Murphy Marcos

title: Inside the ‘Misinformation’ Wars
content: Journalists and academics are developing a new language for truth. The results are not always clearer.

org_facet: Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy

title: Airlines were seeing a travel rebound before Omicron arrived.
content: With several countries imposing new restrictions, the question now is whether travelers will be deterred.

title: ‘Encanto’ Reaches No. 1, but Moviegoers Are Tough to Lure Back
content: No simultaneous streaming: “Encanto” or “House of Gucci” could only be seen in theaters this weekend. Even still, some viewers stayed home.

title: Sylvia Weinstock, the ‘da Vinci of Wedding Cakes,’ Dies at 91
content: She produced floral-draped architectural works in the shape of rose-studded topiaries, baskets of speckled lilies and bouquets of anemones.

title: The Week in Business: Choosing the Same Path
content: President Biden opted for continuity at the Fed, nominating Jerome Powell to a second four-year term. And it’s that time of year — for travel and shopping.
